Description: Fragment of painted raised limestone relief; Hieroglyphic text reading 'Son of Ra'. This fragment from the tomb of Sety I in the Valley of the Kings comes from the king’s titulary. The goose and a red sun-disc read ‘Son of Ra’, which generally preceded the king’s nomen, or birth name. The text is painted on a yellow background and goose is painted blue-green with a red head, red and yellow back, and details of feathers in black. Below is a canal sign in green and blue, likely part of an epithet reading ‘beloved of’ a certain god. The text in the tomb of Seti I was written in vertical columns; the green band at the top indicates the top of the inscription, while the right hand side features a column dividing line and further hieroglyphs, one of them a mouth sign for the letter R.
Curator's comments: The royal tomb of Sety I, from which this relief fragment derives, is the deepest and longest in the Valley of the Kings. It is richly decorated with painted reliefs as well as extensive texts: the first tomb to be decorated with a complete program of religious texts, including the Litany of Ra, Book of the Dead, Amduat, Book of Gates, and Opening of the Mouth ritual.
